elements.content: A new family of oxalate-bridged chains of formula (C1)[Mn(H2O)3Cr(ox)3]·H2O (1), (C2)4[Mn2(H2O)3ClCr2(ox)6]Cl·H2O·2C2H6O (2a), (C2)4[Co2(H2O)3ClCr2(ox)6]Cl·2H2O·2C2H6O (2b), [Mn(C3)(H2O)2Cr(ox)3]·H2O (3), and (C4)4[Mn(H2O){Cr(ox)3}2]·H2O (4) [C1 + = tetramethylammonium, C2 + = 4-N,N-dimethylaminopyridinium, C3 + = 1-hydroxyethyl-4-N,N-dimethylamino-pyridinium, C4 + = 1-hydroxyethyl-4-(4′-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium, ox2– = oxalate] have been synthesized by self-assembly of the (C n )3[Cr(ox)3] (n = 1–4) mononuclear compound and the chloride salts of the corresponding metal(II) ions. The crystal structures of the five chain compounds have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in the Pc and P21/c centrosymmetrical space groups, respectively, whereas 3 and 4 crystallize in the C2cb and P1 noncentrosymmetrical space groups, respectively. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 adopt a zigzag chain structure while 4 exhibits a comb-like chain structure consisting of the repetition of the [Mn(H2O){Cr(μ-ox)(ox)2}{Cr(μ-ox)2(ox)}]4– entities. Compound 3 displays large second-order optical nonlinearity. The magnetic properties of 1–4 have been investigated in the temperature range 2–300 K. Monte Carlo simulations on 1, 2a, 2b, and 3 provide a quantitative description of the magnetic properties indicating ferromagnetic interactions through the bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges [J = +0.55 cm–1 (1), J = +1.02 cm–1 (2a), J = +3.83 cm–1 (2b), and J = +0.75 cm–1 (3) using Hamiltonian Ĥ = −J(Ŝ i ·Ŝ j )]. On the other side, the fit of the magnetic susceptibility data of 4 by full-matrix diagonalization agrees with a ferromagnetic exchange interaction within the [Mn(H2O){Cr(μ-ox)(ox)2}{Cr(μ-ox)2(ox)}]4– trinuclear units (J = +2.07 cm–1) antiferromagnetically coupled along the chain. Compound 2b exhibits a metamagnetic behavior, the value of the critical field being H C = 1000 G, due to the occurrence of weak interchain antiferromagnetic interactions.

The crystal structures of the five chain compounds have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1 and 2 crystallize in the Pc and P21/c centrosymmetrical space groups, respectively, whereas 3 and 4 crystallize in the C2cb and P1 noncentrosymmetrical space groups, respectively. Compounds 1, 2, and 3 adopt a zigzag chain structure while 4 exhibits a comb-like chain structure consisting of the repetition of the [Mn(H2O){Cr(μ-ox)(ox)2}{Cr(μ-ox)2(ox)}]4- entities. Compound 3 displays large second-order optical nonlinearity. The magnetic properties of 1-4 have been investigated in the temperature range 2-300 K. Monte Carlo simulations on 1, 2a, 2b, and 3 provide a quantitative description of the magnetic properties indicating ferromagnetic interactions through the bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges [J = +0.55 cm-1 (1), J = +1.02 cm-1 (2a), J = +3.83 cm-1 (2b), and J = +0.75 cm-1 (3) using Hamiltonian Ĥ = -J(Ŝ  i ⋅Ŝ  j )]. On the other side, the fit of the magnetic susceptibility data of 4 by full-matrix diagonalization agrees with a ferromagnetic exchange interaction within the [Mn(H2O){Cr(μ-ox)(ox)2}{Cr(μ-ox)2(ox)}]4- trinuclear units (J = +2.07 cm-1) antiferromagnetically coupled along the chain. Compound 2b exhibits a metamagnetic behavior, the value of the critical field being H C = 1000 G, due to the occurrence of weak interchain antiferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: A series of oxalate-bridged heterobimetallic one-dimensional compounds, exhibiting a variety of topologies depending on the nature of the organic cation and, eventually, on the presence of coordinated solvent molecules, is structurally and magnetically characterized. Modifying the bridging mode of the oxalate ligand sweeps the exchange interaction between the two metal ions from ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic.
elements.clean_text: A series of oxalate-bridged heterobimetallic one-dimensional compounds, exhibiting a variety of topologies depending on the nature of the organic cation and, eventually, on the presence of coordinated solvent molecules, is structurally and magnetically characterized. Modifying the bridging mode of the oxalate ligand sweeps the exchange interaction between the two metal ions from ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic.

elements.content: Since the pioneering work of Werner on the resolution of tris(oxalato)metalate(III), the oxalato ligand (C2O4 2– = ox) is widely used in coordination chemistry, and a large number of oxalate-based species have been reported with an extended range of magnetic properties. This interest in oxalate ligand is due to the large variety of its coordination modes and to its efficiency to transmit electronic effects between neighboring magnetic centers. Furthermore, the anionic coordination networks [MIIM′III(μ-ox)3]− synthesized from molecular precursors such as tris(oxalato)chromate(III) and a divalent transition metal ion present two other advantages: they can exhibit chirality and welcome a wide variety of functional cations. Such a versatility is an open door toward new classes of hybrid materials and multifunctional molecule-based magnets exhibiting new physical properties. The synthesis and design of new hybrids displaying both magnetic properties and large second-order optical nonlinearities (NLO behavior) are of fundamental interest for chemists, physicists, and materials’ scientists because second harmonic generation (SHG) and electro-optical (EO) devices are important valuable targets. Insertion of hyperpolarizable guests, such as stilbazolium-type chromophores, in magnetic hosts is obviously a suitable strategy.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the pioneering work of Werner on the resolution of tris(oxalato)metalate(III), the oxalato ligand (C2O4 2- = ox) is widely used in coordination chemistry, and a large number of oxalate-based species have been reported with an extended range of magnetic properties. This interest in oxalate ligand is due to the large variety of its coordination modes and to its efficiency to transmit electronic effects between neighboring magnetic centers. Furthermore, the anionic coordination networks [MIIM'III(μ-ox)3]- synthesized from molecular precursors such as tris(oxalato)chromate(III) and a divalent transition metal ion present two other advantages: they can exhibit chirality and welcome a wide variety of functional cations. Such a versatility is an open door toward new classes of hybrid materials and multifunctional molecule-based magnets exhibiting new physical properties. The synthesis and design of new hybrids displaying both magnetic properties and large second-order optical nonlinearities (NLO behavior) are of fundamental interest for chemists, physicists, and materials' scientists because second harmonic generation (SHG) and electro-optical (EO) devices are important valuable targets. Insertion of hyperpolarizable guests, such as stilbazolium-type chromophores, in magnetic hosts is obviously a suitable strategy.

elements.content: Two- (2D) and three- (3D) dimensional heterometallic oxalates are well adapted to wrap around templating counterions (C+). On the contrary, μ-oxalato heterometallic 1D compounds or 0D discrete units are less frequent in this context. To achieve low dimensional systems, blocking ligands substituting one or two oxalate ligands of the building block and/or partially blocking coordination sites of the divalent transition metal ions are efficient but not compulsory.

To achieve low dimensional systems, blocking ligands substituting one or two oxalate ligands of the building block and/or partially blocking coordination sites of the divalent transition metal ions are efficient but not compulsory.

elements.content: We question in the present contribution the possibility to force the 1D dimensionality through parameters such as solubility, steric hindrance, and intermolecular interactions. We report the synthesis, the crystal structure, and the optical and magnetic studies of five heterobimetallic oxalate-bridged chains: C1[Mn(H2O)3Cr(ox)3]·H2O (C1 + = tetramethylammonium; ox = oxalate) (1), (C2)4[M2(H2O)3ClCr2(ox)6]Cl·nH2O·2C2H6O [C2 + = 4-N,N-dimethylaminopyridinium; M = Mn, n = 1 (2a), M = Co, n = 2 (2b)], [Mn(C3)(H2O)2Cr(ox)3]·H2O (3) (C3 + = 1-hydroxyethyl-4-N,N-dimethylamino-pyridinium), and (C4)4[Mn(H2O){Cr(ox)3}2]·H2O (4) (C4 + = 1-hydroxyethyl-4-(4′-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium) (Scheme ). We discuss the parameters that influence their final architecture and their magnetic behavior.

We discuss the parameters that influence their final architecture and their magnetic behavior.

elements.content:
The details of the synthesis are given in the including the synthetic scheme for C4I ().

Physical Techniques

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed by the Service Interdisciplinaire d’Aide à la Recherche et à l’Enseignement (S.I.A.R.E.) of UPMC Paris (France). IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 882 spectrophotometer as KBr pellets. The second harmonic generation (SHG) was measured by the Kurtz-Perry powder technique. By focusing the 1064 nm fundamental of a Nd:YAG nanosecond laser in a 40 atm H2 cell, the 1907 nm beam was generated (Raman effect). This IR beam was focused on microcrystalline powder samples. The generated second harmonic was selected through appropriate filters, detected by a photomultiplier, and the signal was recorded on an ultrafast oscilloscope. The powder samples were put between two glass plates and not calibrated. Calibrated urea powder (80–125 mμ) served as reference. Magnetic measurements were carried out on powdered samples (from single crystals) of 1–4 with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer. Variable-temperature (1.8–300 K) direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility was measured under applied magnetic fields of 1 T (T > 30 K) and 0.01 T (T ≤ 30 K). For 2b, it was further measured between 2 and 10 K for applied magnetic fields between 0.05 and 0.15 T. The alternating current (ac) magnetic susceptibility of 2b was measured at T = 2.0 K with a frequency of 100 Hz. The susceptibility data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms and the sample holder.

Physical Techniques

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed by the Service Interdisciplinaire d'Aide à la Recherche et à l'Enseignement (S.I.A.R.E.) of UPMC Paris (France). IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 882 spectrophotometer as KBr pellets. The second harmonic generation (SHG) was measured by the Kurtz-Perry powder technique. By focusing the 1064 nm fundamental of a Nd:YAG nanosecond laser in a 40 atm H2 cell, the 1907 nm beam was generated (Raman effect). This IR beam was focused on microcrystalline powder samples. The generated second harmonic was selected through appropriate filters, detected by a photomultiplier, and the signal was recorded on an ultrafast oscilloscope. The powder samples were put between two glass plates and not calibrated. Calibrated urea powder (80-125 mμ) served as reference. Magnetic measurements were carried out on powdered samples (from single crystals) of 1-4 with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer. Variable-temperature (1.8-300 K) direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility was measured under applied magnetic fields of 1 T (T > 30 K) and 0.01 T (T ≤ 30 K). For 2b, it was further measured between 2 and 10 K for applied magnetic fields between 0.05 and 0.15 T. The alternating current (ac) magnetic susceptibility of 2b was measured at T = 2.0 K with a frequency of 100 Hz. The susceptibility data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms and the sample holder.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data on single crystals of 1–4 were collected on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer. Crystal parameters and refinement results are summarized in Table . Data collection and data reduction were done with the COLLECT and EVALCCD programs. Empirical absorption corrections were carried out using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. within the WINGX interface. The final geometrical calculations and the graphical manipulations were carried out with PARST97 and CRYSTALMAKER programs, respectively. Main bond lengths and angles for 1–4 are listed in . Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as CCDC-869842 (1), CCDC-869843 (2a), CCDC-869844 (2b), CCDC-869845 (3), and CCDC-869846 (4). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK (fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Data Collection and Refinement

X-ray diffraction data on single crystals of 1-4 were collected on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer. Crystal parameters and refinement results are summarized in Table . Data collection and data reduction were done with the COLLECT and EVALCCD programs. Empirical absorption corrections were carried out using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. within the WINGX interface. The final geometrical calculations and the graphical manipulations were carried out with PARST97 and CRYSTALMAKER programs, respectively. Main bond lengths and angles for 1-4 are listed in . Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as CCDC-869842 (1), CCDC-869843 (2a), CCDC-869844 (2b), CCDC-869845 (3), and CCDC-869846 (4). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK (fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulations were carried out for compounds 1, 2, and 3 by using the decoupled cell method, where the probability of a spin flip is calculated from the exact solution of a model that is made up of the spin under consideration and of its first and second neighbors. The one-dimensional model was built by repeating a cell with 7 sites to reach a total number of centers close to 100. Moreover, periodic boundary conditions were imposed. The number of Monte Carlo steps per site at each temperature was fifty thousand, and one tenth was used in the thermalization process. Finally, the χM T product was evaluated from the magnetization fluctuation. From the results obtained by following this strategy, we have procured empirical laws which allow the simulation of the empirical data and that relate the χM T product with the reduced temperature, T r = T/J, where J is the exchange magnetic coupling expressed in kelvins. The empirical laws used to reproduce the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility for regular chromium(III)–manganese(II) and chromium(III)–cobalt(II) 1D models were obtained by minimizing a quotient between two polynomials through eq : χ M T = g a 2 ∑ i = 0 5 B i ( 1 + A i α 2 ) T r i ∑ i = 0 5 D i ( 1 + C i α 2 ) T r i where χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility per [MnCr] and [CoCr] unit, respectively, and α is the ratio between the Zeeman factors of the MII [M = MnII (S = 5/2) and CoII (S = 3/2)] and CrIII (S = 3/2) ions (α = g M /g Cr). The polynomial coefficients from eq for the [MnCr] and [CoCr] chains are listed in , respectively. F is the agreement factor defined as F = Σ[(χM T)exp – (χM T)calcd]2/Σ[(χM T)exp]2.

elements.content: The crystal structures of the five chain compounds reported in this manuscript share a similar six-coordinate environment for the Cr(III) ions which are surrounded by three bidentate oxalate ligands forming a slightly distorted octahedron in an approximate D3 environment [Cr–O = 1.95–2.01 Å] ().
elements.clean_text:
Results

Description of the Structures

The crystal structures of the five chain compounds reported in this manuscript share a similar six-coordinate environment for the Cr(III) ions which are surrounded by three bidentate oxalate ligands forming a slightly distorted octahedron in an approximate D3  environment [Cr-O = 1.95-2.01 Å] ().

elements.content: Compound 1 consists of anionic oxalate-bridged manganese(II)–chromium(III) zigzag chains running along the [102] direction (Figure ; ). Each Mn(H2O)3Cr(ox)3 unit (Mn–Cr) bears one negative charge. One tetramethylammonium cation per Mn–Cr unit insures the electroneutrality. Within each chain, the tris(oxalato)chromate(III) moiety acts as bis(bidentate) ligand through the carbonyl oxygen atoms of two oxalate groups toward the manganese(II) units (Figure a). Three coordinated water molecules complete the coordination sphere of the manganese(II) ion leading to a hepta-coordinated [MnO7] distorted pentagonal bipyramid (Figure a) [Mn–O = 2.314(2)–2.430(2) Å and Mn–O(w) = 2.119(3)–2.223(2) Å]. The absolute configurations (Δ and Λ) of the Cr(III) centers alternate regularly along the chain leading to achiral zigzag chains (Figure b).

Compound 1 consists of anionic oxalate-bridged manganese(II)-chromium(III) zigzag chains running along the [102] direction (Figure ; ). Each Mn(H2O)3Cr(ox)3 unit (Mn-Cr) bears one negative charge. One tetramethylammonium cation per Mn-Cr unit insures the electroneutrality. Within each chain, the tris(oxalato)chromate(III) moiety acts as bis(bidentate) ligand through the carbonyl oxygen atoms of two oxalate groups toward the manganese(II) units (Figure a). Three coordinated water molecules complete the coordination sphere of the manganese(II) ion leading to a hepta-coordinated [MnO7] distorted pentagonal bipyramid (Figure a) [Mn-O = 2.314(2)-2.430(2) Å and Mn-O(w) = 2.119(3)-2.223(2) Å]. The absolute configurations (Δ and Λ) of the Cr(III) centers alternate regularly along the chain leading to achiral zigzag chains (Figure b).

elements.content: In the crystal lattice, the chains are quite close to each other in the ab plane (Figures b and ). The shortest interchain Cr...Cr, Mn...Mn and Cr...Mn distances are 7.6079(10), 6.4222(9), and 5.9644(10) Å, respectively, whereas the Cr...Mn distances within the chain are in the 5.6096(10)–5.6488(9) Å range. Hydrogen bonds exist between two of the coordinated water molecules and carbonyl oxygen atoms of the adjacent chain [O...O(w) = 2.6701(37)–2.8076(34) Å] and build a honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular motif combining hydrogen and coordination bonds in the ab plane (Figureb). The centers of these hexagonal cells are occupied by the NMe4 + cations. The crystallization water molecules are located between these planes creating a repeating pattern down the c axis (Figure ). They establish hydrogen bonds [O...O(w) = 2.7795(70)–2.8239(69)] with the oxygen atoms of the oxalate groups and one coordinated water molecule of adjacent 2D networks building an overall 3D supramolecular framework (Figure ).

elements.content: Compound 2a consists of two types of anionic oxalate-bridged Cr–Mn zigzag chains running along the [010] direction (Figure ). In the first type of chain, one chloride ion and one coordinated water molecule complete the coordination sphere of the Mn(II) ion whereas in the second type of chain, two water molecules are coordinated to the Mn(II) ion. One noncoordinating chloride ion and four 4-N,N-dimethylamino-pyridinium cations compensate the charge of the two chains. The crystal structure of 2b is disordered: it comprises only one Co(II) ion coordinated to one and a half water molecules and half a chloride ion. In both types of chains, the tris(oxalato)chromate(III) acts as a bis(bidentate) ligand through two of the oxalate groups toward the metal(II) ions (Figure ), leading to the formation of cis isomers of the metal(II) centers. Consequently, both metal atoms exhibit helical chirality. Each metal ion [Cr(III) and M(II)] is connected to a partner of different nature and configuration and chiral zigzag chains are created (Figure ). The gliding mirror of the P21 /c space group generates the second enantiomer and an achiral overall structure.

elements.content: Compound 3 consists of neutral oxalate-bridged manganese(II)–chromium(III) zigzag chains running along the [010] direction (Figures and ; ). The tris(oxalato)chromate(III) entity acts as a bis(bidentate) ligand toward the manganese(II) ion (Figure ). The coordination sphere of this ion is completed by two water molecules [Mn–O(w) = 2.171(2)–2.212(2) Å] and one 1-hydroxyethyl-4-N,N-dimethylamino-pyridinium cation coordinated to the manganese(II) atoms by its terminal alcoholic group [Mn–O = 2.177(2) Å]. The cationic ligand provides a neutral chain. The heptacoordinated [MnO7] unit (Figure ) forms a very distorted pentagonal bipyramid. The absolute configurations of the Cr(III) centers alternate regularly along the chain leading to achiral zigzag chains (Figure ).

elements.content: The packing of the neutral chains in the bc plane is shown in Figure a. In the planes, the neighboring chains are close to each other. The shortest interchain Cr...Cr, Mn...Mn, and Cr...Mn distances are 7.2264(9), 6.4902(9), and 7.3864 Å, respectively, whereas the Cr...Mn distances in the chain are in the range 5.6105(13) and 5.7095(8) Å. The coordinated water molecules are connected to the carbonyl oxygen atoms of the adjacent chains by means of hydrogen bond interactions [O...O(w) = 2.6701(37)–2.8076(34) Å] paving the bc plane by two types of diamond-shaped bimetallic motifs (Figure a). The bigger diamond-shaped cells are occupied by two π-stacked cations [closest contact between the aromatic rings of 3.5407(48) Å] leading to a 2D supramolecular motif combining coordination bonds, hydrogen bonds, and π–π interactions (Figure a). The neutral chains form layers perpendicular to a, with crystallization water molecules located between the planes (Figure b). The crystallization water molecules establish hydrogen bonds with the carbonyl oxygen atoms of the oxalate groups on one side and with a coordinated water molecule of the adjacent A layer on the other side [O(w)...O(w) = 2.7405(33)–2.8463(37) Å] (Figure b). Finally, the coordinated polar cations are stacked in the [010] direction (Figure ) with a resulting net dipolar moment aligned along the a axis. Along the columns, the cations are related to one another by a 140° rotation around the b axis (Figure b). The noncancellation of the dipolar moment at the crystal level, in the non-centrosymmetric C2cb space group, opens the possibility to observe optical nonlinearity.

elements.content: Compound 4 consists of oxalate-bridged branched chains running in the [100] direction, built by the repetition of [Mn(H2O){Cr(ox)3}2]4– units (Figure ; ). Four 1-hydroxyethyl-4-(4′-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium cations ensure the electroneutrality of the compound (Figure b). There are two crystallographically independent chromium(III) units with very similar bond lengths (). On the one hand, Cr(1) acts as bidentate ligand toward the manganese(II) ion through one oxalate group, creating [Mn–Cr] pairs. The two other oxalate ligands do not coordinate. The [Cr(1)(ox)3]3– moiety thus appears as a terminal metalloligand. On the other hand, Cr(2) is surrounded by: (i) one terminal oxalate, (ii) one bidentate oxalate toward [Mn(1)], and (iii) one monodentate oxalate toward [Mn(1b)], leading to the formation of chains along the a axis. In the chain, alternate the usual Mn(1)–(μ-ox-1κ2 O 1 ,O 2 :2κ2 O 3 ,O 4 )–Cr(2) units with a bis(bidentate) coordination of the oxalate bridge [Mn(1)...Cr(2) = 5.4960(8) Å] and Cr(2)–(μ-ox-1κ1 O 1 :2κ2 O 3 ,O 4 )–Mn(1b) units where the monodentate coordination of the oxalate to the manganese lengthens the Cr–Mn distance [Cr(2)...Mn(1b) = 6.1112(8) Å]. Accordingly, the Mn(II) ions have a distorted octahedral environment [MnO6] with five carbonyl oxygen atoms from three oxalate groups of the two [Cr(ox)3]3– entities [Mn–O = 2.144(2)–2.312(2) Å] and one water molecule [Mn–O(w) = 2.133(2) Å] coordinated in a cis position with respect to the monodentate oxalate. Within one chain, both Cr(III) and Mn(II) ions adopt the Λ configuration leading to the formation of chiral helical chains. Due to the absence of improper symmetry element in the P1 space group, the enantiomer is not present in the studied crystal. This indicates either a spontaneous resolution or a conglomerate. The lack of Cotton effect in the circular dichroism (CD) spectra acquired from a bulk sample of 4 (data not shown) confirms the second hypothesis.

elements.content: In 4, the neighboring chains are packed in the ab plane. They interact through a hydrogen bond between one of the oxygen atoms of the terminal oxalate and the water molecule coordinated to the manganese(II) ion O(13)–H(13B)–O(16) [O...O = 2.7156(35) Å] leading to the formation of a square-like two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular motif combining coordination and hydrogen bonds (Figure a). The coordinated water molecule further interacts with the noncoordinating oxygen atom of the monodentate oxalate ligand O(13)–H(13A)–O(6) [O...O = 2.7865(30) Å] (Figure a). In the ab plane, the branched chains are close. The distance between Cr(1) and the nearest manganese center is 8.1869(11) Å whereas the intrachain Cr...Mn distances are 5.4960(8)–5.5694(9) Å (Figure a). Along the c axis, the chains are well separated from each other thanks to the presence of the stylbazonium cations (Figure b): the shortest interchain Cr...Cr, Mn...Mn, and Cr...Mn distance are much larger than those along the other directions, being 10.4156(14), 12.8130(12) and 8.1869(11) Å, respectively. Along the c axis, the unique crystallization water molecule is engaged in two hydrogen bonds between two chains O(20)–H(26A)–O(26)–H(26B)–O(24) [2.8882(35)–2.8309(35)Å].

elements.content: The organization of the hyperpolarizable stilbazonium cations in the P1 non centrosymmetric spacegroup is complex (Figure b). The cations lie with their long axis approximately at 45° of the ac plane and their molecular plane at 45° of the oxalate layers. The cations are uniformly packed in groups of four with a resulting net dipolar moment aligned along the ac plane. However, despite the non-centrosymmetry of the space group, the head-to-tail arrangement of each pair of cations leads to a cancellation of the dipolar moment at the crystal level (Figure b).

elements.content: The ability of the non-centrosymmetric members of this new family of compounds with polar cations to display second harmonic generation (SHG) has been studied under IR light. Despite its noncentrosymmetric P1 space group, compound 4 did not show any observable SHG signal in accordance with the arrangement of the hyperpolarizable cations (Figure b). On the contrary, compound 3 is NLO active with an efficiency up to 5–10 times that of urea at 1.9 μm. The relatively important SHG response is related to the polarizable molecular structure of the 1-hydroxyethyl-4-dimethylaminopyridinium chromophores, and to their noncentrosymmetric packing arrangement. The extended J-type aggregates (Figure ) bring about a large hyperpolarizability.
elements.clean_text:
NLO Properties

The ability of the non-centrosymmetric members of this new family of compounds with polar cations to display second harmonic generation (SHG) has been studied under IR light. Despite its noncentrosymmetric P1 space group, compound 4 did not show any observable SHG signal in accordance with the arrangement of the hyperpolarizable cations (Figure b). On the contrary, compound 3 is NLO active with an efficiency up to 5-10 times that of urea at 1.9 μm. The relatively important SHG response is related to the polarizable molecular structure of the 1-hydroxyethyl-4-dimethylaminopyridinium chromophores, and to their noncentrosymmetric packing arrangement. The extended J-type aggregates (Figure ) bring about a large hyperpolarizability.

elements.content: The direct current (dc) magnetic properties of the chromium(III)–manganese(II) chains in the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per [MnCr] pair for 1, 2a, and 3 and per [MnCr2] unit for 4, and T is the temperature) are shown in Figures (1, 2a, and 3) and (4). The values of χM T at room temperature vary in the narrow range of 6.24–6.37 cm3 mol–1 K for 1, 2a, and 3. They closely correspond to the value calculated for the sum of a CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0] and a high-spin (HS) MnII ion (S Mn = 5/2; g Mn = 2.0) magnetically isolated. For compound 4, the value of χM T at room temperature of 8.18 cm3 mol–1 K is in line with the [MnCr2] stoichiometry.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Manganese(II)-Chromium(III) Chains

The direct current (dc) magnetic properties of the chromium(III)-manganese(II) chains in the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per [MnCr] pair for 1, 2a, and 3 and per [MnCr2] unit for 4, and T is the temperature) are shown in Figures  (1, 2a, and 3) and  (4). The values of χM T at room temperature vary in the narrow range of 6.24-6.37 cm3 mol-1 K for 1, 2a, and 3. They closely correspond to the value calculated for the sum of a CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0] and a high-spin (HS) MnII ion (S Mn = 5/2; g Mn = 2.0) magnetically isolated. For compound 4, the value of χM T at room temperature of 8.18 cm3 mol-1 K is in line with the [MnCr2] stoichiometry.

elements.content: Upon cooling, χM T for 1, 2a, and 3 increases slowly in the 300–30 K temperature range, then it increases much rapidly to reach maxima at 3.7 and 4.3 K with χM T values of 10.1 (1) and 25.3 (2a) cm3 mol–1 K, respectively. For 3, χM T reaches 26.3 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K without maximum. χM maxima are observed at 2.5 K for 1 and 2.6 K for 2a. For 4, χM T increases and presents a maximum at 7.5 K (χM T = 9.47 cm3 mol–1 K) and then decreases. For the four compounds, the increase of χM T when decreasing the temperature is the signature of an intrachain ferromagnetic coupling. The decrease observed at low temperature for 1 and 2a reveals weak interchain antiferromagnetic interactions (J′) in the two compounds the intensity of which is related to the temperature where the value of the maximum of χM T occurs |J′(2a)| > |J′(1)| > |J′(3)|.

For 3, χM T reaches 26.3 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K without maximum. χM maxima are observed at 2.5 K for 1 and 2.6 K for 2a. elements.content: The magnetization M vs the applied magnetic field H plots for 1, 2a, and 3 at 2.0 K are shown in Figure b. The saturation values (7.56–7.88 Nβ at 5.0 T) are reached rapidly and they are consistent with a S = 4 ferromagnetic spin ground state of the [MnCr] pairs. For 4, the M S value (9.66 Nβ at 5.0 T) fits well with a ferromagnetic alignment of the spins in the [MnCr2] unit. Nevertheless, the higher fields necessary to reach the saturation reveal antiferromagnetic interactions between the [MnCr2] fragments.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 1, 2a, and 3 was modeled through Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) calculations by using a bimetallic 1D model (see in ). The QMC polynomial expression of χM T (eq ) was used for a least-squares fitting of the experimental data in the temperature ranges 10–300 K (1 and 2a) and 1.8–300 K (3) (Figure a). The values of the best-fit parameters are J = +0.55 (1), +1.02 cm–1 (2a) and +0.75 cm–1 (3), g Cr = g Mn = 1.99 (1), 2.02 (2a), and 1.98 (3) with F = 1.6 × 10–5 (1), 1.4 × 10–5 (2a), and 3.3 × 10–5 (3).

The QMC polynomial expression of χM T (eq ) was used for a least-squares fitting of the experimental data in the temperature ranges 10-300 K (1 and 2a) and 1.8-300 K (3) (Figure a). The values of the best-fit parameters are J = +0.55 (1), +1.02 cm-1 (2a) and +0.75 cm-1 (3), g Cr = g Mn = 1.99 (1), 2.02 (2a), and 1.98 (3) with F = 1.6 × 10-5 (1), 1.4 × 10-5 (2a), and 3.3 × 10-5 (3).

elements.content: For compound 4, we first considered the magnetic susceptibility of independent trinuclear [MnCr2] units by full-matrix diagonalization of the isotropic spin Hamiltonian (eq ) within the mean field approximation with S Mn = 5/2 and S Cr1 = S Cr2 = 3/2: H ∧ = − J [ S ∧ Mn · S ∧ Cr 1 + S ∧ Mn · S ∧ Cr 2 ] + g Mn S ∧ Mn H + g Cr [ S ∧ Cr 1 + S ∧ Cr 2 ] H where J is the intramolecular exchange interaction through the bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges within the trinuclear units.

elements.content: The interactions between the trinuclear units were then taken into account by introducing a Curie–Weiss temperature θ. The fitted curve closely follows the experimental data in the temperature range 2–300 K (Figure a). The least-squares fit of the experimental data gives g = g Cr = g Mn = 2.00, J = +2.07 cm–1, and θ = −2.35 cm–1.

elements.content: The structure reveals that the interchain contacts in 4 should be weak as in 1–3. Accordingly, we suggest that the negative Curie–Weiss parameter determined for 4 is essentially due to the antiferromagnetic intrachain exchange interaction between the [MnCr2] units.

elements.content: The χM T versus T plot for 2b (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per [CoCr] pair) is shown in Figure a. The value of χM T at room temperature is 4.40 cm3 mol–1 K. It corresponds to the sum of a magnetically isolated CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0) and a HS octahedral CoII ion (S Co = 3/2) with an important orbital contribution (g Co = 2.5). Upon cooling, χM T increases suggesting a ferromagnetic intrachain interaction (Figure a), and reaches a maximum at 3.7 K (40.0 cm3 mol–1 K) before decreasing abruptly.
elements.clean_text:
Cobalt(II)-Chromium(III) Chains

The χM T versus T plot for 2b (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per [CoCr] pair) is shown in Figure a. The value of χM T at room temperature is 4.40 cm3 mol-1 K. It corresponds to the sum of a magnetically isolated CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0) and a HS octahedral CoII ion (S Co = 3/2) with an important orbital contribution (g Co = 2.5). Upon cooling, χM T increases suggesting a ferromagnetic intrachain interaction (Figure a), and reaches a maximum at 3.7 K (40.0 cm3 mol-1 K) before decreasing abruptly.

elements.content: The susceptibility of 2b becomes field dependent for T < 6 K (Figure b). A maximum is observed for applied magnetic inductions lower than 0.1 T (Figure b) and disappears at higher values. This suggests a field-induced transition from an antiferromagnetic to a ferromagnetic ground state. The sigmoidal shape of the isothermal M vs H plots (Figure a) with a crossing point at ca. 0.1 T, agrees with a metamagnetic-like behavior. The transition from an antiferro- to a ferromagnetic ordering is confirmed by the sharp peak at 0.1 T of the out-of-phase ac molar magnetic susceptibility χ″M vs H.

elements.content: The nature of the exchange interaction found in the studied one-dimensional compounds is the same as in the previously described discrete oxalate-bridged polynuclear complexes. For compounds 2 and 4, the magnitude of the exchange is comparable to the previously observed values whereas, for compounds 1 and 3, it drops below 1 cm–1, at significantly lower values than generally observed in Mn(II)–Cr(III) oxalate-bridged systems.

elements.content: In the present work, we take advantage of the versatility of molecular chemistry to combine oxalate-bridged bimetallic architectures with polar cations within the same material. The former partner is chosen for its magnetic properties whereas the latter may introduce properties related to its polar character, e.g. aminopyridinium derivatives are indeed known for their ferroelectric properties, whereas 4-(4′-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium exhibits nonlinear optical properties both in solution and in the solid state. From a synthetic point of view, the use of (NH4)3[Cr(ox)3]·3H2O is a valuable way for introducing tris(oxalate)chromate(III) in a mixed water/organic solvent to solubilize organic partners. However, we recently demonstrated that the ammonium ion may compete with the organic cation in templating the oxalate-bridged architecture. Thus, we performed a metathesis from (NH4)3[Cr(ox)3]·3H2O toward (C x )3[Cr(ox)3]·nH2O before introducing the metal(II) salt in solution. We obtained various topologies in a series of one-dimensional compounds, a dimensionality scarcely observed in bimetallic oxalate-bridged systems. Recent examples have reported the insertion of 1-methyl-4-(4′-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium as counterion in 1D compounds whereas this cation has been previously introduced in 2D oxalate-bridged bimetallic networks. We try, in the following paragraphs, to identify and to understand the parameters that control the dimensionality and the topology of the compounds to allow their rational synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

In the present work, we take advantage of the versatility of molecular chemistry to combine oxalate-bridged bimetallic architectures with polar cations within the same material. The former partner is chosen for its magnetic properties whereas the latter may introduce properties related to its polar character, e.g. aminopyridinium derivatives are indeed known for their ferroelectric properties, whereas 4-(4'-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium exhibits nonlinear optical properties both in solution and in the solid state. From a synthetic point of view, the use of (NH4)3[Cr(ox)3]⋅3H2O is a valuable way for introducing tris(oxalate)chromate(III) in a mixed water/organic solvent to solubilize organic partners. However, we recently demonstrated that the ammonium ion may compete with the organic cation in templating the oxalate-bridged architecture. Thus, we performed a metathesis from (NH4)3[Cr(ox)3]⋅3H2O toward (C x )3[Cr(ox)3]⋅nH2O before introducing the metal(II) salt in solution. We obtained various topologies in a series of one-dimensional compounds, a dimensionality scarcely observed in bimetallic oxalate-bridged systems. Recent examples have reported the insertion of 1-methyl-4-(4'-dimethylamino-α-styryl)-pyridinium as counterion in 1D compounds whereas this cation has been previously introduced in 2D oxalate-bridged bimetallic networks. We try, in the following paragraphs, to identify and to understand the parameters that control the dimensionality and the topology of the compounds to allow their rational synthesis.

elements.content: The first important point is to use a robust, magnetic building block. This is the main reason for the choice of the [Cr(ox)3]3– moiety. It is stable due to the chelating property of oxalate and inert because of the d3 electronic structure of the chromium(III). In all the described compounds, the [Cr(ox)3]3– precursor is fully preserved as a D 3 symmetry synthon. The [Cr(ox)3]3– anionic complex is a good Lewis base able to strongly bind metallic Lewis acids in three different spatial directions, a feature well suited for the complex-as-ligand strategy, which is an important milestone in the rational design of complex metal–organic architectures.
elements.clean_text: The first important point is to use a robust, magnetic building block. This is the main reason for the choice of the [Cr(ox)3]3- moiety. It is stable due to the chelating property of oxalate and inert because of the d3 electronic structure of the chromium(III). In all the described compounds, the [Cr(ox)3]3- precursor is fully preserved as a D 3 symmetry synthon. The [Cr(ox)3]3- anionic complex is a good Lewis base able to strongly bind metallic Lewis acids in three different spatial directions, a feature well suited for the complex-as-ligand strategy, which is an important milestone in the rational design of complex metal-organic architectures.

elements.content: The second important point is the choice of the second metallic precursor to open access to various coordination environments. A divalent cation allows obtaining an anionic [M(II)Cr(III)(ox)3]− repeating unit preparing the later insertion of the third partner, i.e. the organic cation. The heteroleptic character of the M(II) center, with a potentially variable coordination environment is as important as the homoleptic character of the Cr(III). The choice of Mn(II) and, to a lesser extent, Co(II) guarantees the flexibility of the coordination sphere. The Mn(II) radius and the Mn(II)-ligand distances are larger than those observed with the other divalent transition metal ions because of the antibonding role of the eg electrons in an octahedral surrounding. It makes it possible to accommodate more ligands and to reach coordination numbers higher than six. Indeed, important variations in the environment of the metal(II) ion can be observed in the series of compounds herein described. In 2 and 4, the metal(II) is hexacoordinated, while in 1 and 3, the manganese(II) ion is heptacoordinated. Octacoordinated Mn(II) centers have also been observed in oxalate-bridged compounds. Obviously, this Mn(II) coordination versatility can open routes to other dimensionalities when varying the synthetic conditions. For example, a change from hexa- to hepta-coordination influences the organization of 2D networks but does not prevent their formation whereas a 3D network implying octacoordinated manganese(II) has been described.

elements.content: The third important point is the oxalate ligand itself. The versatility of the coordination mode of this ligand is well-known and well exemplified in this series of compounds: it remains terminal as observed in 1–4; it binds to the metal(II) ion in a monodentate mode as found in 4 for one of the oxalate or, most often, in a bidentate manner leading to the bis(bidentate) bridging situation in 1–4. The monodendate binding mode of the metal(II) ion is scarce. It has been previously observed in a 2D network. The coexistence around the Cr(III) of one nonbonding mode and two bis(bidentate) modes of the oxalate is crucial to get 1D compounds (1–4).

The monodendate binding mode of the metal(II) ion is scarce. It has been previously observed in a 2D network. elements.content: A fourth important point is the choice of the synthetic conditions to offer the suitable ligands to complete the coordination sphere of the metal(II) ion: solvent (water, alcohol), ancillary anions (chloride), organic cations. The Lewis base character of these potential ligands controls the coordination. The nature of each coordinated ligand opens the way to different intermolecular interactions and hence different topologies. Three different coordinated ligands are present in this study. First, a chloride ion is coordinated to the metal(II) ion in one type of the chains encountered in 2. It has only a blocking role. It is neither bridging nor implied in H-bonding. Second, water molecules are coordinating in 1, 2, and 4. They occupy a M(II) coordination position but they are also implied in hydrogen bonds with neighboring molecules. Third, in 3, the amino-pyridinium C3 + acts as a ligand through its alcoholic functional group. This last case appears surprising. It has never been observed before and it contrasts with the one observed for the polymorph of formula (C3)[MnCr(ox)3(CH3CH2OH)] which consists of 2D anionic [MnCr(ox)3(C2H5OH)]− layers, interleaved by stacks of the polar cation C3 + whereas the neutral ethanol molecule is coordinated to manganese(II). The ratio EtOH–H2O in the reaction mixture is the key point that accounts for the shift between the two structures. A competition exists between the two weak Lewis bases alcohols [ethanol and 4-N,N-dimethylamino-1-hydroxyethylpyridinium] to coordinate the Lewis acidic manganese(II) ions. When using a slow diffusion technique (ethanol diffusion in aqueous solution), the ethanol concentration is not high enough to prevent 4-N,N-dimethylamino-1-hydroxyethyl-pyridinium cation from coordinating and the neutral 1D compound 3 crystallizes in the polar aqueous solvent. The electrostatic interaction between the anionic network and the organic cation helps the coordination process. Instead, when using a 9:1 EtOH–H2O ratio, the ethanol molecules coordinate, the C3 + cation and the anionic network remain in solution, and the system crystallizes after some days in a completely different thermodynamic potential well and 2D structure.

elements.content: Another important feature in this series of compounds is that the [Cr(ox)3]3– moiety essentially acts as bis(bidentate) metalloligand. This behavior is scarce and contrasts with its tris(bidentate) metalloligand ability in the formation of 2D and 3D metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). In 4, [Cr(ox)3]3– even acts as a single connector leading to an original branched topology. This behavior is similar to what has been observed in the formation of dinuclear and trinuclear complexes. In all the cases where the coordination connectivity of the chromium(III) complex is restricted, the terminal oxalates are engaged in hydrogen bonds that imply coordination or coordinated water molecules. This competition between hydrogen and coordination bonds appears as an essential point to prevent the formation of coordination extended networks. It should be noted that, in most cases, the coordination and hydrogen bonds combine to form complex supramolecular motifs that are reminiscent of those observed in extended coordination networks as shown in Figures and . In 1, the tetramethylammonium cation sits strictly in the 2D supramolecular anionic network, whereas in purely coordinative oxalate-bridged 2D networks, only one alkyl of tetraalkylammonium enters into the cell. Because of this location, despite a smaller overall size, the tetramethylammonium cation prevents the ring closure toward the usual purely coordinative honeycomb motifs and favors the observed supramolecular organization with elongated honeycomb cells. The situation is comparable in 3: the coordinated cation C3 + of two adjacent chains are π-stacked at the center of a supramolecular honeycomb motif (Figure a). The ring closure is then ensured by H-bonds between the terminal oxalate of one chain and the alcoholic function of C3 + on the one hand [O(12)–O(13) = 2.7069(32) Å] and between the second terminal oxygen atom of the oxalate and a coordinated water molecule on the other hand. This last case indicates that when functional groups are chosen to favor the introduction of new physical properties, the prediction of the structure is more difficult. These actors deeply modify the possible intermolecular interactions and hence make new topologies possible. This is particularly true with polar functional groups able to establish hydrogen and coordination bonds as those we are currently studying for introducing SHG and ferroelectric properties. In turn, it appears that such cations tend to favor the formation of low dimensional systems.

elements.content: Even if we understand better how to reach the various topologies, we should recognize that, at the present stage, important features are still out of a priori control: (i) the subtle weak supramolecular interactions tuning the Madelung energy which determines the exact organization of the molecular ions in the ionic crystal; (ii) the non centrosymmetrical character of the space groups of 3 (C2cb) and 4 (P1); the appearance of a unique enantiomer from a initial racemic bath is still an intriguing problemand ever fascinating for living organismsand one of our present lines of research.

elements.content: Concerning the nonlinear optical (NLO) properties, despite the presence of hyperpolarizable cations in 2a, 2b, 3, and 4, only compound 3 was found to be NLO active. Complexes 2a and 2b belong to the centrosymmetric P21/c space group, which accounts for their NLO inactivity. Compound 4, despite its crystallization in a noncentrosymmetric space group (P1), presents an average centrosymmetrical organization of the polar cations (see structural section) preventing the observation of these properties.
elements.clean_text: Concerning the nonlinear optical (NLO) properties, despite the presence of hyperpolarizable cations in 2a, 2b, 3, and 4, only compound 3 was found to be NLO active. Complexes 2a and 2b belong to the centrosymmetric P21/c space group, which accounts for their NLO inactivity. Compound 4, despite its crystallization in a noncentrosymmetric space group (P1), presents an average centrosymmetrical organization of the polar cations (see structural section) preventing the observation of these properties.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of the one-dimensional compounds 1–4 are examined in the light of the crystal structure. They are influenced by both the 1D structures and by the interchain interactions. In all the compounds 1–4, the [Cr(ox)3]3– moiety provides three unpaired electrons in t 2g orbitals considering the CrO6 polyhedron as an octahedron. On the other hand, Mn(II) provides five unpaired electrons (three t 2g, two e 2g when the manganese(II) surrounding is octahedral). When the bridging oxalate is bis(bidentate) (i) the Cr(t 2g) and Mn(t 2g) orbitals weakly overlap and the corresponding antiferromagnetic interactions are weak; (ii) the Cr(t 2g) and Mn(e g) orbitals are orthogonal and provide a significant ferromagnetic contribution specially through the Mn d x2–y2 orbital. The overall interaction is therefore weak and ferromagnetic. DFT calculations confirm this analysis and underline that we are located close to the crossing point between the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic regime depending on the details of the structure of the bridge. In compounds 1, 2a, 3, and 4, we retrieve a weak ferromagnetic Mn(II)–Cr(III) exchange interaction mediated by the bis(bidentate) oxalate ligand. In compound 4, it is also found within the [MnCr2] units. The Mn(II)–Cr(III) ferromagnetic interaction is experimentally robust in the bis(bidentate) coordination mode though we observe a weakening of the interaction when the coordination sphere of the manganese(II) departs from the octahedron. This variation is somehow reflected by the drop of TC in 2D oxalate-bridged compounds where such a coordination of the manganese(II) is observed. Thanks to the quantitative treatment of the magnetic susceptibility in low dimensional systems, it is possible to quantify this influence of the change of coordination environment of the manganese(II) ion.

This variation is somehow reflected by the drop of TC in 2D oxalate-bridged compounds where such a coordination of the manganese(II) is observed. Thanks to the quantitative treatment of the magnetic susceptibility in low dimensional systems, it is possible to quantify this influence of the change of coordination environment of the manganese(II) ion.

elements.content: The influence of the bridging mode of the oxalate is more dramatic than the one of the manganese coordination sphere, and appears as the key parameter governing the nature of the coupling: the exchange interaction sweeps from ferromagnetic for the bis(bidentate) bridging mode to antiferromagnetic for the bidentate–monodentate bridging mode observed between the [MnCr2] trinuclear units of 4, as once previously observed. This rocking from a ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic exchange interaction is related to the switch from strict orthogonality in the Mn(e g)–Cr(t 2g) exchange pathways to increased overlap upon oxalate bridge dissymmetrization.

This rocking from a ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic exchange interaction is related to the switch from strict orthogonality in the Mn(e g)-Cr(t 2g) exchange pathways to increased overlap upon oxalate bridge dissymmetrization.

elements.content: The interchain interactions (hydrogen bond contacts, π–π interactions, etc.) are also reflected in the magnetic properties. 1 and 2a show maxima in the χM T vs T plots because of the antiferromagnetic coupling coming from an efficient interaction between neighboring chains. On the contrary, in 3, despite the fact that the neighboring chains are close to each other no maximum in the χM T vs T plot is observed, indicating that this structural feature is not reflected by the magnetic properties in the observed temperature range. More dramatically, these antiferromagnetic interactions, associated with the larger magnetic anisotropy of the CoII ions, are responsible for the metamagnetic behavior with a H C value of 1000 G observed in compound 2b.

elements.content: In this manuscript, we have described the synthesis and the structural, NLO, and magnetic properties of five bimetallic oxalate-bridged chains. By using (C x )3[CrIII(ox)3] salts as precursors, the synthetic strategy combined the well-known “complex-as-ligand” strategy with a preliminary metathesis to restrict the possibilities of self-assembly and increase the predictability of the system evolution. The use of the [CrIII(ox)3]3– unit yielded in all cases one-dimensional compounds where at least one of the oxalate ligands remained nonbridging in contrast with the well-known 2D or 3D bimetallic metal–organic frameworks. Up to date, this bis(bidentate) coordination mode was only seen in a few one-dimensional and discrete trinuclear compounds. We speculate that the polar cations play an important role in the assembly process, whether by means of insolubility of the formed species, steric hindrance, or intermolecular interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this manuscript, we have described the synthesis and the structural, NLO, and magnetic properties of five bimetallic oxalate-bridged chains. By using (C x )3[CrIII(ox)3] salts as precursors, the synthetic strategy combined the well-known "complex-as-ligand" strategy with a preliminary metathesis to restrict the possibilities of self-assembly and increase the predictability of the system evolution. The use of the [CrIII(ox)3]3- unit yielded in all cases one-dimensional compounds where at least one of the oxalate ligands remained nonbridging in contrast with the well-known 2D or 3D bimetallic metal-organic frameworks. Up to date, this bis(bidentate) coordination mode was only seen in a few one-dimensional and discrete trinuclear compounds. We speculate that the polar cations play an important role in the assembly process, whether by means of insolubility of the formed species, steric hindrance, or intermolecular interactions.

elements.content:
The inclusion of hyperpolarizable chromophores in these ferromagnetic systems yielded SHG active magnets when a noncentrosymmetric assembly of the chromophores was reached as in the case of 3.

The variety of architectures observed for these five compounds is reflected in their magnetic behavior. 1 and 2a show maxima in the χM vs T plots related to significant antiferromagnetic interchain interactions whereas the isolation of the chains in 3 prevents the presence of a maximum of χM in the explored temperature range. More dramatically, the metamagnetic behavior of compound 2b is due to the combination of weak interchain antiferromagnetic interactions together with the magnetic anisotropy of Co(II) ions. The variations of the coordination environment of the metal(II) ions as well as the two bridging modes of the oxalate observed along this series of compounds lead to the conclusion that the key parameter of the M(II)–Cr(III) exchange interaction is the bridging mode of the oxalate rather than the coordination number or the nature of the oxalate coligands of the metal(II) ion: a bis(bidentate) bridging mode favors a ferromagnetic exchange between the neighboring metal ions whereas a bidentate–monodentate bridging mode leads to an antiferromagnetic interaction.

cln_elements.content:
The direct current (dc) magnetic properties of the chromium(III)–manganese(II) chains in the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per [MnCr] pair for 1, 2a, and 3 and per [MnCr2] unit for 4, and T is the temperature) are shown in Figures (1, 2a, and 3) and (4). The values of χM T at room temperature vary in the narrow range of 6.24–6.37 cm3 mol–1 K for 1, 2a, and 3. They closely correspond to the value calculated for the sum of a CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0] and a high-spin (HS) MnII ion (S Mn = 5/2; g Mn = 2.0) magnetically isolated. For compound 4, the value of χM T at room temperature of 8.18 cm3 mol–1 K is in line with the [MnCr2] stoichiometry.

Cobalt(II)–Chromium(III) Chains

The χM T versus T plot for 2b (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per [CoCr] pair) is shown in Figure a. The value of χM T at room temperature is 4.40 cm3 mol–1 K. It corresponds to the sum of a magnetically isolated CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0) and a HS octahedral CoII ion (S Co = 3/2) with an important orbital contribution (g Co = 2.5). Upon cooling, χM T increases suggesting a ferromagnetic intrachain interaction (Figure a), and reaches a maximum at 3.7 K (40.0 cm3 mol–1 K) before decreasing abruptly.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Manganese(II)-Chromium(III) Chains

The direct current (dc) magnetic properties of the chromium(III)-manganese(II) chains in the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per [MnCr] pair for 1, 2a, and 3 and per [MnCr2] unit for 4, and T is the temperature) are shown in Figures  (1, 2a, and 3) and  (4). The values of χM T at room temperature vary in the narrow range of 6.24-6.37 cm3 mol-1 K for 1, 2a, and 3. They closely correspond to the value calculated for the sum of a CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0] and a high-spin (HS) MnII ion (S Mn = 5/2; g Mn = 2.0) magnetically isolated. For compound 4, the value of χM T at room temperature of 8.18 cm3 mol-1 K is in line with the [MnCr2] stoichiometry.

Cobalt(II)-Chromium(III) Chains

The χM T versus T plot for 2b (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per [CoCr] pair) is shown in Figure a. The value of χM T at room temperature is 4.40 cm3 mol-1 K. It corresponds to the sum of a magnetically isolated CrIII ion (S Cr = 3/2; g Cr = 2.0) and a HS octahedral CoII ion (S Co = 3/2) with an important orbital contribution (g Co = 2.5). Upon cooling, χM T increases suggesting a ferromagnetic intrachain interaction (Figure a), and reaches a maximum at 3.7 K (40.0 cm3 mol-1 K) before decreasing abruptly.
